title: 114_s1989
content: The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" may be cited as the Act. It addresses the treatment of direct primary care service arrangements. The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" addresses the treatment of direct primary care service arrangements by amending the Internal Revenue Code to exclude such arrangements from being considered as health plans or insurance. The amendment excludes direct primary care service arrangements from being considered as health plans or insurance. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include periodic provider fees as medical care. This applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 establishes the Medicare Primary Care Medical Home Demonstration Program. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include a Primary Care Medical Home Model where qualified practices are reimbursed a periodic fee for services provided to individuals enrolled under Medicare Part B. The Primary Care Medical Home Model reimburses qualified practices for services provided to individuals enrolled under Medicare Part B. The Primary Care Medical Home Model reimburses qualified practices for services provided to individuals enrolled under Medicare Part B, including qualified direct primary care medical home practices as defined in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The Secretary establishes a periodic fee for these practices. The Secretary establishes a periodic fee for qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the Primary Care Medical Home Model under Medicare Part B. The fee cannot exceed a certain amount per individual enrolled in the practice. The Secretary sets a fee for direct primary care medical home practices in the Primary Care Medical Home Model under Medicare Part B, limited to twenty percent of estimated monthly payments from Medicare funds. The Secretary establishes a fee for direct primary care medical home practices in the Primary Care Medical Home Model under Medicare Part B, set at twenty percent of estimated monthly payments from Medicare funds. A performance benchmark is also established using ACO quality measures. The Secretary establishes a performance benchmark for direct primary care medical home practices in the Medicare shared savings program under section 1899. Beginning in the second year of the model, adjustments are made for qualified practices. In the Medicare shared savings program under section 1899, adjustments are made for qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model. If a practice meets or exceeds the performance benchmark, they receive a periodic fee for each individual. If a direct primary care medical home practice meets or exceeds the performance benchmark, the periodic fee paid to the practice for each individual enrolled will be increased by 5 percent. If the practice does not meet the performance benchmark, the periodic fee remains the same. If a direct primary care medical home practice does not meet the performance benchmark for two consecutive years, the Secretary will terminate their participation. The participation of a qualified direct primary care medical home practice in the model will be terminated if they do not meet the performance benchmark for two consecutive years. Each qualified direct primary care medical home practice must provide preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, and coordinate primary care with specialty and hospital care. The direct primary care medical home practice must offer preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, coordination with specialty and hospital care, availability of ongoing care appointments 7 days a week, secure e-mail and telephone consultation, and 24/7 telephone access for ongoing care consultation. The direct primary care medical home practice must offer preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, coordination with specialty and hospital care, availability of ongoing care appointments 7 days a week, secure e-mail and telephone consultation, and 24/7 telephone access for ongoing care consultation, with a primary care provider panel size that promotes the ability to provide services. The direct primary care medical home practice must offer preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, coordination with specialty and hospital care, availability of ongoing care appointments 7 days a week, secure e-mail and telephone consultation, and 24/7 telephone access for ongoing care consultation, with a primary care provider panel size that promotes the ability to provide services. The Secretary shall prioritize practices enrolling dual eligible individuals. The Secretary prioritizes direct primary care medical home practices enrolling dual eligible individuals, who are enrolled in part B of title XVIII and meet specific criteria under the Social Security Act. The term 'dual eligible individual' refers to someone enrolled in part B of title XVIII and meeting specific criteria under the Social Security Act. Care provided in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under this model is not considered insurance. Care provided in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under this model is not considered an insurance product and is not subject to regulation by State insurance commissioners. A qualified direct primary care medical home practice under this model is not considered an insurance product and is not subject to regulation by State insurance commissioners. The practice must submit an annual report to the Secretary on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions, including emergency room visits and hospitalizations. The subsection requires the practice to submit an annual report to the Secretary on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions, including emergency room visits, hospitalizations, surgeries, specialist visits, and advanced radiology use. Additional areas determined appropriate by the Secretary may also be included in the report. The Secretary shall provide qualified direct primary care medical home practices with necessary patient data for clinical purposes and reporting on chronic conditions, including surgeries, specialist visits, and advanced radiology use. The Secretary will provide direct primary care practices with patient data for clinical purposes and evaluation of the model. Physicians who have opted out of Medicare can also participate. Physicians who have opted out of Medicare can participate in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under the model, with payment made for services provided to Medicare beneficiaries under a private contract. Physicians excluded from federal health care programs cannot participate in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under the model. The Secretary will conduct the model for a minimum of 3 years, and if after the third year it is determined that the model is successful, expansion may occur. The Secretary will conduct the model for at least 3 years, and if successful after the third year, expansion may occur for qualified direct primary care medical home practices. The model for qualified direct primary care medical home practices will continue permanently if requirements are met, with potential expansion after the third year. The model for qualified direct primary care medical home practices will continue permanently if requirements are met, with potential nationwide expansion if a majority of practices meet specified criteria. The use of direct primary care medical homes under the Medicare Advantage program is addressed in Section 5. Section 5 addresses the use of direct primary care medical homes in the Medicare Advantage program, allowing Medicare Advantage organizations to contract with qualified practices for primary care services and shared savings agreements. The Medicare Advantage program allows organizations to contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices for primary care services and shared savings agreements. A qualified direct primary care medical home practice is defined as described in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
